sentence: Mice harbouring established NFpp10-GBM tumours were treated with intravenous injections of LIGHT–CGKRK fusion compound twice weekly for 2weeks (Figure 2A), and this was followed by histological analysis of tumour stroma.

LIGHT–VTP therapy at a dose of 20ng per mouse (≈600ng/kg body weight) significantly reduced tumour vessel length and diameter as compared with untreated GBM, to a level resembling the calibre of normal brain capillaries (Figure 2B–D).
Importantly, overall vascularity was not reduced, indicating that single LIGHT–CGKRK treatment did not destroy tumour vessels (Figure 2E).

LIGHT–VTP treatment did not change the number of pericytes that were attached to endothelial cells as compared with untreated tumours, as shown by quantification of desmin-positive pericytes surrounding CD31+ tumour blood vessels (Figure 3A).
Under LIGHT–VTP treatment, all contractile markers were significantly upregulated, whereas synthesis of the extracellular matrix marker collagen I was reduced (Figure 3B–E).

Mice harbouring established NFpp10-GBM tumours were treated with intravenous injections of LIGHT–CGKRK fusion compound twice weekly for 2weeks (Figure 2A), and this was followed by histological analysis of tumour stroma.

LIGHT–VTP therapy at a dose of 20ng per mouse (≈600ng/kg body weight) significantly reduced tumour vessel length and diameter as compared with untreated GBM, to a level resembling the calibre of normal brain capillaries (Figure 2B–D).
Importantly, overall vascularity was not reduced, indicating that single LIGHT–CGKRK treatment did not destroy tumour vessels (Figure 2E).

LIGHT–VTP treatment did not change the number of pericytes that were attached to endothelial cells as compared with untreated tumours, as shown by quantification of desmin-positive pericytes surrounding CD31+ tumour blood vessels (Figure 3A).
Under LIGHT–VTP treatment, all contractile markers were significantly upregulated, whereas synthesis of the extracellular matrix marker collagen I was reduced (Figure 3B–E).
